metadata.title: Baking Polymer Clay - Everything you need to know to properly cure clay (& your FAQ's answered!)

transcription.full_text: Hello and welcome to the MyClayCo studio. I am Tegan and today we are going to be talking about baking polymer clay. Now easily the most frequently asked questions that land in our inbox are all around baking and curing polymer clay so we wanted to do a whole video on it for you today. We are going to be sharing our top tips as well as the crucial things that you need to know and we're also going to be answering some of those frequently asked questions that we get. Before we get into our top tips one of the things that you should know about polymer clay is that it should be a bit bendy once it's baked properly. That's because unlike some other clays it does have plasticizers added to it so it means that once it is cured it does have that slight flex to it. So if you are baking your polymer clay and do find that it's a bit flexible afterwards congratulations you have cured your polymer clay correctly. If you're not finding this, if you're finding that your polymer clay is brittle once it's baked you can snap it in half or when you're drilling jump ring holes it's just crumbling around the hole then you definitely need to be careful. If you're finding that your polymer clay is brittle once it's baked you can watch this video. Let's get into those top tips. The first two tips that I'm going to give you are probably the most crucial things that you need to know when you're baking your polymer clay. So number one is the temperature. So temperature seems like an easy thing. The packet says bake at 130 degrees so you turn your oven to 130 degrees but it doesn't bake correctly. Now this is quite often because ovens are fickle things and although you've got the temperature set at 130 degrees it might not actually be baking at 130 degrees. So you need to be careful. If you're baking your polymer clay at 130 degrees you might find that it's baking at 110 degrees or it's baking at 150 degrees which quickly becomes a problem because you're going to find that your clay is either going to be over baked or under baked. So if your clay is under baked it can mean that your pieces will be brittle whereas if it's over baked you might find that your clay burns. So it's really crucial that you know what temperature your oven is baking at. Sit tight because I have another tip for you in a moment that will help with this issue. So that were two crucial things. The second crucial thing is the baking time. Now with polymer clay quite often the baking time is around 30 minutes depending on the thickness of your pieces. It is important that you bake it for this minimum baking time. So if you're going to be baking it for 10 or 15 minutes you probably will find that it's under baked. Now something that is interesting about polymer clay is that you can't really over bake it so long as the temperature of your oven is correct. So for example if you were to leave your clay pieces in the oven for 40 minutes or 50 minutes or an hour you will likely find that they come out just as they would if you baked them for the 30 minutes. And this is one of the fabulous things about polymer clay because it means that you can bake it, add details to it, bake it again, add more details and even bake it a third time. It's become a bit of a joke in the studio that I quite often forget about my pieces and I don't set an alarm and they're in there for an hour or so. It's true she leaves them in there all the time like sometimes but over an hour I have to take them out all the time. So if you do leave them in there for longer than that minimum baking time don't stress they will likely be fine. So the crucial thing to know is that you need to have them in there for that minimum baking time but if you do leave them in there a little bit longer it's not going to cause any harm. Now I said I would have a tip for you around the baking temperature and that is to use an oven thermometer. Now oven thermometers are quite inexpensive you can normally pick them up for 10 or 15 dollars from a hardware store or Kmart or Target and that will mean that you're baking at an accurate temperature. So even if your oven dial is saying that it's baking at 130 and your oven's at 150 you'll know. Our next tip is to follow the manufacturer's instructions. You might find that different brands of clay have different recommended baking temperatures or different recommended baking times so it's really important that you read what it says on the packet to ensure that you don't underbake or overbake your oven. Make sure that you preheat your oven just as you would if you were baking cookies or something. If you don't preheat your oven you run that risk that your pieces are not going to be baking at the correct temperature for the right amount of time and they'll end up underbaked. Our final tip is to test. So before you get started you want to make sure that you can find your oven's optimal baking time and temperature. You might find that your oven dial should be set at 150 degrees whereas somebody else might find that theirs should be set at 110. If you're using a different oven you might want to make sure that you're baking at the right temperature. If you're using a different oven you might want to make sure that you're baking at the right temperature. If you're using a different oven you might want to make sure that you're baking at the right temperature. If you're using a different oven you really depends on the oven that you're using. So if you're just starting out you've got a new oven we recommend doing some white tester pieces. Now the reason why we say white is because it will be easy to tell if your oven temperature is too hot because you'll be able to see that they're slightly burnt whereas if you do your tester pieces in a darker color you may not notice this. So get your tester pieces pop them in the oven and from there you can adjust the temperature higher or lower depending on what you find it needs. Now I promised at the start that I would be using a different oven but I promised at the start that we would go through a few of the frequently asked questions that we get so here they are. Why is my polymer clay bendy? We've already touched on this polymer clay does have plasticizers in it so unlike some other clays it will be bendy if it is cured correctly. Why is my clay brittle once it's baked? So there generally are two reasons for this. So one of them is going to be all of the baking temperature and time stuff that we've discussed today. The other reason it could be though is the type of clay that you're using. A common thing that we see for beginners is that they start making jewelry with Sculpey 3. Now Sculpey 3 is an excellent modeling clay but it isn't so good for making earrings and you will probably find that if you do make earrings out of Sculpey 3 that it will be brittle once it's baked. So if you are looking to use Sculpey clay we recommend using Sculpey Primo or Sculpey Souffle. There are a range of other clays out there on the market like the Cernut range, Fimo Professional that are also excellent. So these are some of the top tips that I would suggest to you before making jewelry with so just do your research before you try out a new clay. Can I increase the temperature that I'm baking at to make my pieces bake quicker? No, your pieces will burn. Do I need to tent my pieces? Now for those that don't know what tenting is basically it means just putting a piece of foil over your clay while it's baking so that the tops of them don't burn. Now we don't ever tent our pieces and we don't find that our pieces burn so it might be that for those people that it could be that the element in their oven is quite close to their clay pieces while they're baking and this can be quite common in toast ovens. So I would just test to see if you need to tent your pieces. If you do find that you've got your clay baking at the correct temperature and it is still burning then it is something that you can explore and see if it works for you. What baking surface do I bake my pieces on? Now this is going to come down to personal preference as well. So we almost always bake our pieces on a gloss ceramic tile. We like working on gloss ceramic tiles and we can then just pop them in the oven afterwards. But there are a range of other things that you can bake on. Some of the common ones that we see are either baking paper or also just normal copy paper. So again have a play around and find out what works for you. Do I need a special oven to bake polymer clay in? No, you don't need a special oven. It's not like some other ceramics that you can get at the supermarket. So you can just pop them in the oven and bake them in. If you have a few other ceramics where you need to put them in a kiln, you can bake polymer clay in your normal ordinary oven. Now if you don't want to bake in your normal oven that is totally fine. You can look at one of those mini toaster oven options. You will probably find though that they do seem to be a little bit more fickle with getting the right temperature. So you will probably have to do just a little bit more testing to make sure that you get your baking temperature correct. Can I bake in an air fryer? So we actually tested this and found that we could bake in an air fryer. So you could cure our clay correctly in an air fryer. So it probably wouldn't be my first option because if your clay pieces aren't stuck down to your tile, they will whiz around in there and probably destroy them. But I guess it is an option is probably just not the best option. Can I bake my pieces in the same oven that I cook food in? While polymer clay isn't food safe, it is non-toxic. So yes, you can bake your pieces in your normal oven. It is recommended though. Don't use a normal oven. Don't bake food and clay in there at the same time. And if you are to burn your clay in the oven, I would definitely recommend giving your oven a proper clean before using it again for food. I hope you found our tutorial on baking polymer clay helpful today. If you do have any questions, we would love to help you out. Just drop them in the comments below. Otherwise, please, if you have enjoyed it, like and subscribe and we will see you next time.

emotion_analysis.note: Emotion analysis requires additional audio preprocessing

frames.analysis:
1. Lighting Problems:
   - Uneven illumination of the subject matter, with certain areas appearing overly bright or dim compared to others.
   - Shadows cast by nearby objects, which can detract from the details of the items being displayed.

2. Lighting Solutions or Techniques Demonstrated:
   - Use of additional lighting fixtures (possibly including the pink light source) to fill in shadows and provide a more even distribution of light across the scene.
   - Adjustment of the natural light entering the room, which may have been diffused or redirected to avoid glare and harsh shadows.

3. Specific Lighting Products Mentioned or Shown:
   - The pink light source is likely a supplementary lighting device, such as a LED panel, flashlight, or desk lamp, used to create a soft pink light on the items, enhancing their color and appearance.

4. Lighting Context:
   - This appears to be a crafting space where various items, including jewelry and decorative pieces, are displayed. The task is likely related to designing, creating, or showcasing these items, possibly for sale or exhibition purposes. The mood of the image suggests a bright, creative, and welcoming environment designed to highlight the colorful details of the items and make them look more appealing.

In this image, we see a person standing in front of a craft store display area with various craft supplies and items for sale. The person appears to be presenting or demonstrating something related to the products.

1. Lighting Problems or Challenges:
   - Shadows: There are shadows on the wall behind the person, which could indicate an uneven light source distribution.
   - Ambient Lighting: The overall ambient lighting seems to be soft and diffused, with no harsh spots that might create glare or make certain products difficult to see.

2. Solutions or Techniques Demonstrated:
   - Product Display Illumination: The items on display are well-lit, allowing potential customers to clearly view the details of the products.
   - Natural Light: There is natural light coming through the window to the left of the person, which can help create a warm and inviting atmosphere.

3. Specific Lighting Products or Techniques Shown:
   - Natural Light: The use of natural light helps in avoiding artificial light for certain areas, which can be energy-efficient and create a more natural aesthetic.
   - Ambient Lighting: The ambient lighting seems to consist of soft ceiling lights that provide even illumination without creating harsh shadows.

4. Context (Room Type, Task, Mood):
   - Room Type: This image depicts the interior of a craft store or an area designated for showcasing products for sale.
   - Task: The task seems to be product presentation or demonstration, possibly explaining the use or features of a particular item or line of items.
   - Mood: The mood appears to be casual and informative, with the person presenting in a relaxed manner. The soft lighting suggests a calm and comfortable environment for shopping or browsing.

1. Lighting Problems/Challenges: The image shows uneven lighting with hotspots on the subject's face, particularly noticeable around the eyes and nose area. There is no visible fill light to soften shadows.

2. Lighting Solutions/Techniques: No specific product or solution is mentioned or shown in this frame. However, based on the pain points identified above, one could suggest using a diffuser or reflector to soften light, an additional light source to provide more even illumination, and possibly a hair light to reduce shadows on the face, especially around the eyes.

3. Lighting Context (Room Type, Task, Mood): The room appears to be an indoor space with natural light coming through windows or another source of light not visible in the frame. The task is related to personal grooming, as indicated by the presence of scissors. The mood is casual and everyday, suggesting a common or mundane activity being performed.

4. Overall Pain Points: Unbalanced lighting on the subject's face with hotspots, lack of fill light causing shadows, possibly insufficient overall lighting for a clear and well-lit image.

5. Possible Solutions: Diffusing the light source, adding more ambient light or additional light sources, using hair lights to minimize shadows around the eyes, adjusting the lighting setup to create a softer, more even illumination on the subject's face.

1. There's a visible glare from the camera flash on the woman's face, which can be distracting and may affect the overall quality of the video.

2. The woman appears to be using a tablet, which suggests that she is demonstrating or discussing something related to the content displayed on the screen. However, since we are focusing on lighting aspects, it seems like there is no specific lighting product being demonstrated in this particular frame.

4. The room appears to be an indoor space with shelves containing items that might need to be well-lit for display or recognition purposes. Since there is no specific task or mood being established, we can infer that the lighting is meant to provide a neutral and comfortable environment for the woman to engage with the content on her tablet. However, the glare indicates that there may not be sufficient ambient light in the room to minimize reflections from flash-equipped devices during the filming process. This could lead to undesirable visual effects or discomfort for the subject being filmed.

2. Lighting solutions or techniques demonstrated: The use of a lighted front window of the oven allows for better visibility of the inside during operation, reducing the need to open the oven door prematurely and improving energy efficiency by reducing heat loss.

3. Specific lighting products mentioned or shown: There is no visible brand or product name in this frame. However, the use of an illuminated front window suggests the application of LED lighting technology which can be more energy-efficient than traditional incandescent bulbs.

4. Lighting context (room type, task, mood): The image shows a kitchen setting where the focus is on the functionality and efficiency of the oven's lighting system during cooking tasks. The illuminated front window provides an improved level of visibility for these tasks, while also enhancing the overall ambiance of the kitchen with its warm, inviting glow.

1. Lighting Problem: The image shows several objects with a mix of ambient light sources, including overhead lights casting shadows and uneven illumination. This suggests that the current lighting setup is not providing even and well-distributed light, which can affect visibility and aesthetic appeal of the objects in the display.

2. Lighting Solution: The image is likely demonstrating a technique for creating a soft, diffused light by using materials with translucent properties. In this case, colored foils are being used to diffuse the light coming from behind the items, creating an even glow without harsh shadows. This soft lighting effect can be used for various purposes, such as displaying crafts, art pieces, or merchandise in a way that highlights their details and creates an inviting atmosphere.

3. Specific Lighting Product Mentioned: The foils mentioned are serving as diffusers to create the desired lighting effect. While we can't see the actual product or brand, it is clear that these materials are being used to achieve a particular lighting aesthetic.

4. Lighting Context: The context of the image appears to be a crafts display area where decorative items are showcased. The presence of foils and the use of soft light for display suggests that the goal is to make the displayed items look more appealing by providing a pleasant, non-glaring lighting environment.

1. Visible lighting problems: The image shows a woman standing in front of a rack filled with colorful fabric items, possibly cards or books. There's insufficient lighting on her face, which might make it difficult for customers to see the products clearly or create an engaging shopping experience. The ambient lighting is soft and does not seem to provide sufficient illumination for detailed visibility.

The task at hand is sales and product presentation, requiring bright and clear lighting to attract customers and allow them to fully appreciate the merchandise. The mood of the scene suggests that the woman is engaged in her work, attempting to overcome the current lighting challenges by using personal interaction to communicate effectively with shoppers.

1. The woman in the image appears to be slightly underexposed, which can make her face look flat and may reduce the visual interest of the photo.

2. To address this issue, the photographer could have used a fill light or reflected light to evenly illuminate the subject's face without creating harsh shadows. Additionally, they could have adjusted the camera settings for proper exposure or balanced the lighting conditions by using a combination of natural and artificial light sources.

3. No specific lighting products are visible in the image. However, given the context, it is possible that the woman is in a store with various light sources, such as shop lights and ambient interior lighting.

4. The setting appears to be an indoor retail environment, likely a store specializing in crafts or DIY supplies. The task could involve selling items, engaging customers, or presenting products. The mood seems casual and friendly, which is appropriate for a commercial or retail setting.

In the image provided, it appears to be an indoor setting with a person standing in front of a shop counter that has various crafting supplies. The lighting in the scene is not evenly distributed; there are shadows cast on the right side of the frame by the subject against the light source. This could indicate insufficient or unbalanced lighting, creating uneven illumination and potentially making the subject appear as if only half of their face is lit.

One possible solution for this situation could be to add a secondary light source on the opposite side to provide more even illumination, reducing shadows and improving overall lighting in the room. Additionally, considering the presence of bottles that might contain products that require good lighting for display, ensuring proper ambient lighting or additional task lighting around specific areas of interest (like the crafting supplies) could be beneficial.

As for the mood of the room, it seems casual and relaxed, with a pinkish tone that might suggest either an artificial light source with a warmer color temperature or a soft, diffused natural light source. The lighting could be adjusted to create a more inviting atmosphere if necessary.

There are no specific lighting products visible in this image, but the solutions mentioned above (additional light sources) could involve using various types of lamps, overhead fixtures, or even portable LED panels that can easily be repositioned for optimal light distribution.

In summary, the current setup shows an imbalance in lighting, with shadows on the right side. The use of additional light sources and possibly adjusting the ambient color temperature could improve the overall lighting quality within this room.

1. The lighting in the room appears to be artificial and quite bright, possibly from overhead track lighting or recessed ceiling lights. There are no visible shadows cast by the subject, which might indicate that the light sources are too high or there is a lack of soft diffused light at lower levels to create depth or contrast.

2. The person in the video seems to be demonstrating how to use a small handheld lighting device. This could be used for tasks requiring precise illumination, such as painting nails or working with small objects that require detailed visibility.

3. The presence of various makeup products and nail polish bottles suggests that these items are meant to be displayed under good light conditions. Therefore, the individual is likely emphasizing the importance of adequate lighting in such retail or beauty environments for product display and customer engagement.

4. The context of this image seems to be a store setting with a focus on personal grooming products. The task being performed involves using the demonstrated handheld lighting device to inspect a small object, perhaps a nail polish bottle, which requires precision and visibility. The mood appears to be educational, aiming to convey information about how appropriate lighting can enhance tasks related to beauty or crafts.

The image shows a social media post with a quote overlaid on an image of a cake. The quote reads: "Why is my clay brittle once it's baked?" This suggests that the poster might be interested in improving the texture of their clay after baking.

1. Lighting Problems/Challenges: There are no specific lighting problems or challenges visible in this image. It appears to be a standard lighting setup, which is typical for photographing food items like cakes, as it provides even illumination to show the details of the cake without casting harsh shadows.

2. Lighting Solutions/Techniques: The image itself does not provide any specific solutions or techniques related to baking clay. It's more about sharing a common problem experienced by those who work with clay.

3. Lighting Products Mentioned/Shown: There are no visible lighting products mentioned or shown in the context of this image. The focus is on the cake and the quote rather than any specific lighting equipment.

4. Lighting Context: The context of the image seems to be a discussion about baking, as indicated by the quote. It could relate to an artistic project, a craft activity, or a culinary endeavor where someone is experiencing issues with their clay after baking. However, there are no visible details in the image that directly address the baking process or the specific lighting challenges related to this context.

The image appears to be a composite video frame showing two hands holding small decorative items. The hand in the foreground is holding an item with a blue pattern, while the other hand holds a matching set of the same item.

1. Lighting Problems:
   - There are no visible shadows or highlights on the items themselves, suggesting that there might be insufficient lighting to create a dramatic effect or to highlight the details and textures of the items. The even lighting could make it challenging to show the three-dimensional form of the decorations.

2. Lighting Solutions:
